test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to change plan immediately online, forced to wait until next billing cycle or contact support
test_cases.test_scenario: Test immediate plan change functionality on the web portal
preconditions: Customer has an active account
Customer has used most of their data for the current cycle
Customer attempts to change plan online
test_steps: Step 1: Login to the customer portal with a test account
Step 2: Navigate to the plan management section
Step 3: Attempt to change the plan to a higher tier with more data
Step 4: Verify if the system allows for an immediate plan change or prompts to wait until the next billing cycle
test_cases.expected_result: The system should allow for an immediate plan change with a prorated charge or offer alternative options such as a data add-on
test_cases.actual_issue: The system currently does not allow for immediate plan changes online, causing customer frustration and unnecessary support calls
edge_cases: Test with varying data usage levels
Test with multiple account types (e.g. individual, family)
test_cases.customer_impact: High - customers experience frustration and inconvenience when unable to change plans immediately, leading to potential churn and negative reviews

test_cases.issue_description: Port request gets stuck due to missing middle initial in customer's name
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the web portal's activation form includes fields for middle initials or handles names with middle initials correctly
preconditions: Customer has a Verizon account with a middle initial in their name
Customer has purchased a new phone from the Total Wireless website
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the web portal and navigate to the device activation page
Step 2: Enter a test customer's information, including a name with a middle initial, and Verizon account details
Step 3: Submit the activation request and verify that the port request is processed successfully
Step 4: Verify that the form includes fields for middle initials or that the system can handle names with middle initials correctly
test_cases.expected_result: The port request is processed successfully, and the customer's phone is activated without delays
test_cases.actual_issue: The port request gets stuck due to the missing middle initial in the customer's name, causing service delays and customer dissatisfaction
edge_cases: Test with different types of names (e.g., names with suffixes, prefixes, or multiple middle initials)
Test with different Verizon account information (e.g., different account types, billing addresses)
test_cases.customer_impact: Service delays, customer dissatisfaction, and potential loss of business due to poor customer experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer is charged for international roaming without notification when phone connects to a stronger foreign tower near the border
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that the system provides notifications or warnings to customers when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, especially in border areas
preconditions: Customer has an active international roaming plan
Customer is near the US-Mexico border with a stronger Mexican tower signal
Customer's phone is set to automatically connect to the strongest available tower
test_steps: Step 1: Simulate customer's phone connecting to a foreign tower in a border area
Step 2: Verify that the system generates a roaming notification or warning to the customer
Step 3: Check that the customer's account is correctly updated with the roaming charges
Step 4: Test with different phone settings, such as manual network selection, to ensure the notification is still triggered
test_cases.expected_result: The customer receives a notification or warning when their phone connects to a foreign tower for roaming, and their account is correctly updated with the roaming charges
test_cases.actual_issue: Customers are not receiving notifications or warnings when their phone connects to a foreign tower, resulting in unexpected roaming charges
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with international roaming capabilities
Stronger foreign tower signal in a border area
Web portal for billing and account management
edge_cases: Customer has a phone set to manual network selection
Customer is in an area with multiple foreign towers
Customer has a limited or pay-per-use international roaming plan
test_cases.customer_impact: Unexpected roaming charges and lack of transparency in billing, leading to customer frustration and potential churn

test_cases.issue_description: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page for device purchase
test_cases.test_scenario: Verify that pricing information is consistent and clearly indicates any conditions (e.g. new line activation) on the product page and checkout page
preconditions: User is logged in to their account
User has an existing line to upgrade
User selects a device with conditional pricing (e.g. new line activation)
test_steps: Step 1: Navigate to the product page of a device with conditional pricing (e.g. Samsung Galaxy A54)
Step 2: Verify the price displayed on the product page
Step 3: Proceed to checkout with the selected device and an existing line to upgrade
Step 4: Verify the price displayed on the checkout page
Step 5: Check for any clear indications of conditional pricing (e.g. 'Price includes new line activation discount') on both the product page and checkout page
test_cases.expected_result: The price displayed on the product page and checkout page should be the same, and any conditions affecting the price (e.g. new line activation) should be clearly indicated on both pages
test_cases.actual_issue: Pricing discrepancy between product page and checkout page due to unclear conditional pricing information
edge_cases: Test with different devices and pricing conditions (e.g. new line activation, bundle discounts)
Test with different user account scenarios (e.g. new customer, existing customer with multiple lines)
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer time wasted, trust, and potential loss of sales due to pricing confusion

test_cases.issue_description: Plan change buttons are non-responsive for customers with multiple add-ons
test_cases.test_scenario: Test plan change functionality for customers with multiple add-ons
preconditions: Customer has an account with multiple add-ons (e.g. international calling and mobile hotspot)
Customer is using a supported browser (e.g. Chrome)
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the customer portal with a test account that has multiple add-ons
Step 2: Navigate to the plan change page
Step 3: Click on the plan options buttons
Step 4: Verify that the plan change feature responds as expected
test_cases.expected_result: The plan change buttons respond correctly, allowing the customer to change their plan
test_cases.actual_issue: The plan change buttons are non-responsive, preventing the customer from changing their plan
edge_cases: Test with different combinations of add-ons
test_cases.customer_impact: Silent failures, preventing customers from managing their accounts effectively

test_cases.issue_description: Existing customers are unable to apply promotional codes intended for new customers, despite receiving emails with valid codes
test_cases.test_scenario: Test that promotional codes are correctly validated based on customer type (new or existing) and that relevant terms and conditions are clearly communicated
preconditions: Existing customer account with associated email address
Promotional code sent to existing customer email address
Promotional code is intended for new customers only
test_steps: Step 1: Log in to the web portal as an existing customer
Step 2: Attempt to apply the promotional code to a purchase
Step 3: Verify that the system correctly identifies the customer as existing and prevents code application
Step 4: Check the email and promotional code terms for clarity on eligibility criteria
test_cases.expected_result: The system should prevent the existing customer from applying the promotional code, and the email and promotional code terms should clearly indicate that the code is only valid for new customers
test_cases.actual_issue: Existing customers are able to attempt to apply promotional codes intended for new customers, resulting in 'code not valid' errors and customer frustration
edge_cases: Test with different types of promotional codes and customer accounts
Test with multiple attempts to apply the code
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer frustration and potential loss of trust in the company due to unclear or misleading promotional offers

test_cases.issue_description: Mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed
test_cases.test_scenario: Test device upgrade feature on Android devices with varying number of installed apps
preconditions: Android device with Total Wireless mobile app installed
More than 100 apps installed on the device
Device upgrade option available in the app
test_steps: Step 1: Launch the Total Wireless mobile app on an Android device
Step 2: Navigate to the device upgrade section
Step 3: Select a new device for upgrade
Step 4: Verify if the app crashes or throws an error
Step 5: Repeat steps 2-4 with different numbers of installed apps (e.g., 50, 100, 150) to identify the threshold for the crash
test_cases.expected_result: The mobile app should allow device selection and upgrade without crashing, regardless of the number of installed apps
test_cases.actual_issue: The mobile app crashes when selecting a new device for upgrade on Android devices with more than 100 apps installed, due to memory management issues
edge_cases: Test with a large number of background apps running
test_cases.customer_impact: Core functionality unavailable on mobile, forcing customers to use alternative channels, resulting in a poor customer experience

test_cases.issue_description: Customer unable to disable auto-pay in mobile app when enrolled through website
test_cases.test_scenario: Test disabling auto-pay in mobile app for accounts enrolled in auto-pay through website
preconditions: Customer has an account with auto-pay enabled through the website
Customer has the latest version of the mobile app installed
test_steps: Step 1: Enable auto-pay for a test account through the website
Step 2: Log in to the mobile app with the test account credentials
Step 3: Navigate to 'Account Settings' and then 'Payment Settings'
Step 4: Verify if the option to disable auto-pay is available
Step 5: Attempt to disable auto-pay through the mobile app
test_cases.expected_result: The option to disable auto-pay is available and functional in the mobile app
test_cases.actual_issue: The option to disable auto-pay is not available in the mobile app for accounts enrolled through the website
environmental_dependencies: Mobile device with latest OS version
Latest version of the mobile app
test_cases.customer_impact: Customer is unable to manage their account features through their preferred channel, leading to frustration and potential churn
